problem.tex: State the following, clearly and completely: (a) What it means for a complex-valued function to have an isolated singularity. (b) What it means for a complex-valued function to have a pole. (c) Some version of Cauchy's integral formula giving the value of $f^{(k)}$ for an analytic function $f$.

solution.tex: a) Suppose $\Omega$ is a region in $\mathbb{C}$ and that there is some $a\in\mathbb{C}, r>0$ such that $B_r(a)\cap\Omega=B_r(a)\setminus\{a\}$. Then we say that a holomorphic function $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ has an isolated singularity at $a$. b) Suppose $\Omega$ is a region and $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ has an isolated singularity at $a\in\mathbb{C}$. We say that $f$ has a pole at $a$ if $\lim_{z\to a}|f(z)|=\infty$. c) Let $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ be holomorphic and let $a\in\Omega, r>0$ be such that $\overline{B_r(a)}\subset\Omega$. Then for all integers $k\geq0$, \[\frac{2\pi i}{k!}f^{(k)}(a)=\int_{|z-a|=r}\frac{f(z)}{(z-a)^{k+1}}dz.\]
